titleStmt.title: AN OVERVIEW OF DISTANCE AND SIMILARITY MEASURES OF INTUITIONISTIC FUZZY SETS

affiliation.orgName: Department of Management Science and Engineering

analytic.title: AN OVERVIEW OF DISTANCE AND SIMILARITY MEASURES OF INTUITIONISTIC FUZZY SETS

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: The Intuitionistic Fuzzy Sets (IFSs), originated by Atanassov [1], is a useful tool to deal with vagueness and ambiguity. In the short time since their first appearance, many different distance and similarity measures of IFSs have been proposed, but they are scattered through the literature. In this paper, we give a comprehensive overview of distance and similarity measures of IFSs. Based on the weighted Hamming distance, the weighted Euclidean distance, and the weighted Hausdorff distance, respectively, we define some continuous distance and similarity measures for IFSs. We also utilize geometric distance model to define some continuous distance and similarity measures for IFSs, which are the various combinations and generalizations of the weighted Hamming distance, the weighted Euclidean distance and the weighted Hausdorff distance. Then we extend these distance and similarity measures for Interval-Valued Intuitionistic Fuzzy Sets (IVIFSs).

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In [2], Zadeh introduced the concept of fuzzy set whose basic component is only a membership function with the non-membership function being one minus the membership function. However, in real-life situations, when a person is asked to express his/her preference degree to an object, it is possible that he/she is not so sure about it, that is, there usually exists a hesitation or uncertainty about the degree, and there is no means to incorporate the hesitation or uncertainty in a fuzzy set. Later, Atanassov [1] gave a generalized form of fuzzy set, called Intuitionistic Fuzzy Set (IFS), which is characterized by a membership function and a non-membership function. Deschrijver and Kerre [3] established the relationship between IFSs, Interval-Valued Intuitionistic Fuzzy Sets (IVIFSs) [4], L-fuzzy sets [5], and Interval-Valued Fuzzy Sets (IVFSs) [6], and showed that IVFS theory is equivalent to IFS theory, which was also noticed or emphasized by several other scholars (e.g. Atanassov and Gargov [4], Dubois et al. [7,8], Cornelis et al. [9]). Recently, there is some debate about the appropriateness of the terminology "IFS" [8,10]. Dubois et al. [8] pointed out that there is a terminological clash between IFS and intuitionistic logic. They differ both by their motivations and their underlying mathematical structure. In reply to [8], Atanassov [10] discussed the relationship between the notion of Atanassov's IFS and the notion proposed by Takeuti and Titani [11] under the same name. He argued that IFS defined by himself is derived from the fact that the truth-values of the elements of these sets satisfy the condition that sum of both degrees of membership and of non-membership is smaller or equal to 1. It exactly corresponds to the ideal of the notion of intuitionism proposed by Brouwer [12]. But here we are not involved in this discussion and use the traditional name, i.e. IFS. IFSs have been proven to be highly useful to deal with uncertainty and vagueness, in the short time since their first appearance, many authors have paid great attention to the measures of distance and similarity, and correlation between IFSs. In this paper, we give a comprehensive overview of distance and similarity measures of IFSs. To do so, the remainder of the paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we review some basic concepts and operations related to IFSs. Section 3 makes a comprehensive survey of distance and similarity measures of IFSs. Based on the weighted Hamming distance, the weighted Euclidean distance, and the weighted Hausdorff distance, respectively, we define some continuous distance and similarity measures. Based on geometric distance model, we also define some continuous distance and similarity measures, which are the various combinations and generalizations of the weighted Hamming distance, the weighted Euclidean distance and the weighted Hausdorff distance. We generalize the similarity measures of Mitchell [13] and furhter define their continuous counterparts. Based on geometric distance model and set-theoretic approach, in Section 4 we develop a variety of distance and similarity measures for IVIFSs. Section 5 concludes the paper.

div.head: An Overview of Distance and Similarity Measures of IFSs
div.p: Distance and similarity measures, and correlation analysis of IFSs are an important research topic in the IFS theory, which has received much attention from researchers. Gerstenkorn and Mafiko [14] defined a function measuring the correlation of IFSs, and introduced a coefficient of such a correlation. Bustince and Burillo [15] introduced the concepts of correlation and correlation coefficient of IVIFSs. They also introduced two decomposition theorems of the correlation of IVIFSs, one in terms of the correlation of interval-valued fuzzy sets and the entropy of IFSs, and the other theorem in terms of the correlation of IFSs. Hong and Hwang [16] studied the concepts of correlation and correlation coefficient of IFSs in probability spaces. Hong [17] generalized the concepts of correlation and correlation coefficient of IVIFSs in a general probability space and generalized the results of Bustince and Burillo [15]. Hung and Wu [18] proposed a method to calculate the correlation coefficient of IFSs by means of ''centroid''. The method not only reflects the strength of relationship between IFSs, but also whether the IFSs are positively or negatively related. Furthermore, they extended the ''centroid'' method to IVIFSs. Xu [19] gave a recent survey on correlation analysis of IFSs, and proposed a new method for deriving the correlation coefficients of IFSs, which has some advantages over the existing methods. Furthermore, the developed method was extended to the IVIFS theory, and its application was shown in medical diagnosis.

In the following, we make a comprehensive overview of distance and similarity measures of IFSs, and propose some new distance and similarity measures for IFSs. We first introduce the concept of similarity measure of IFSs defined by Li and Cheng [20]:

div.p: Bustince [21] defined the following distances:
1) The normalized Hamming distance:
div.formula: 1 1 1 ( , ) (| ( ) ( ) | | ( ) ( ) | 2 n A j B j A j B j j d A B x x v x v x n µ µ = = - + - ∑(9)
div.p: 2) The normalized Euclidean distance:
div.formula: 2 2 2 1 1 ( , ) (( ( ) ( )) ( ( ) ( )) 2 n A j B j A j B j j d A B x x v x v x n µ µ = = - + - ∑(10)
div.p: The distance measure (9) first calculates the absolute values of difference between each two membership degrees and between each two non-membership degrees of A and B, then divides the sum of all these absolute values by 2n. The distance measure (10) first calculates the square values of difference between each two membership degrees and between each two non-membership degrees of A and B, then divides the sum of all these square values by 2n, and finally gets its square root. Obviously, these two distance measures only involve the first two parameters: the membership degree and the nonmembership degree describing IFSs.

In [22], Szmidt and Kacprzyk gave a geometrical representation of distances between IFSs, and showed the distance measures should take into account all three parameters of IFSs, that is, the third parameter (the degree of indeterminacy) should not be omitted when calculating distance between IFSs. As a result, they proposed the following distances:
1) The normalized Hamming distance:
div.formula: 3 1 1 ( , ) (| ( ) ( ) | | ( ) ( ) | | ( ) ( ) | 2 n A j B j A j B j A j B j j d A B x x v x v x x x n µ µ π π = = - + - + - ∑(11)
div.p: 2) The normalized Euclidean distance:
div.formula: 2 2 2 4 1 1 ( , ) (( ( ) ( )) ( ( ) ( )) ( ( ) ( )) 2 n A j B j A j B j A j B j j d A B x x v x v x x x n µ µ π π = = - + - + - ∑(12)
div.p: Taking into account all three parameters describing IFSs when calculating distances ensures that the distances for IFSs can be easily compared.

In [23], Szmidt and Kacprzyk defined a similarity measure combining the distance measure of A and B, and the distance measure of A and B c : can be calculated by using (11) or (12). The similarity measure (13) involves both similarity and dissimilarity, and has the following properties [23]:

1) s 1 (A, B) = 0 means the identity of A and B; 2) s 1 (A, B) = 1 means that A is to the same extent similar to B and B c ; 3) s 1 (A, B) → +∞, i.e., A = B c (or A c = B) means the complete dissimilarity of A and B (or the identity of A and B c ); 4) A = B = B c means the highest entropy [24] for both elements A and B.

div.p: The prominent characteristic of the similarity measures ( 13) and ( 14) is that: they take into account not only a pure distance between IFSs but also examine whether the compared IFSs are more similar or more dissimilar to each other. This desirable characteristic makes it possible to avoid drawing conclusions about strong similarity between IFSs on the basis of the small distances between these sets [23].

The Hausdorff distance [30] is a measure of how much two non-empty compact (closed and bounded) sets A and B in a metric space resemble each other with respect to their positions, it obeys the properties of identity, symmetry and triangle inequality. Hung and Yang [31] presented a method to calculate the distance between IFSs on the basis of the Hausdorff distance (55), which is described as follows:

The similarity measures (71)-( 74) are straightforward and easy for applications. Wang and Xin [33] showed that the normalized Hamming distance measure satisfy the conditions of the metric and has some good geometric properties, but in reality it may not fit so well. To overcome this drawback, they defined the following distance:
div.formula: 22 1 | ( ) ( ) | | ( ) ( ) | ( , ) 4 µ µ = - + -  =   ∑ n A j B j A j B j j j x x v x v x d A B w max{| ( ) ( ) |, | ( ) ( ) |} 2 A j B j A j B j x x v x v x µ µ - -  +  (75)
div.p: Clearly, the distance measure (75) is the combination of the normalized Hamming distance and Hausdorff distance. It not only can satisfy all the conditions of the metric, but also can avoid the unreasonable results produced by the normalized Hamming distance in practical applications.

div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: The authors are very grateful to the Editor and the anonymous reviewers for their insightful and constructive comments and suggestions that have led to an improved version of this paper. The project was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Nos. 70571087 and 70621061) and the National Science Fund for Distinguished Young Scholars of China (No. 70625005).

Obviously, the similarity measure (83) is based on the weighted Euclidean distance and Hausdorff metric, and the similarity measure (84) is the continuous counterpart of the similarity measure (83).

div.head: Distance and Similarity Measures of IVIFSs
div.p: Consider that, sometimes, it is not approximate to assume that the membership degrees for certain elements of an IFS are exactly defined, but a value range can be given. In such cases, Atanassov and Gargov [4] introduced the notion of Interval-Valued Intuitionistic Fuzzy Set (IVIFS), which is characterized by a membership function and a nonmembership function, whose values are intervals rather than exact numbers [34]:
Let a set X be fixed, an IVIFS A ~ over X is an object having the form:
For convenience, let ) ( ~X Φ be the set of all IFSs of X, and let
, then two of their relations and operations are defined as follows [4]:
Below we give the concept of similarity measure of IVIFSs:
, which satisfies the following properties:
which satisfies the following properties:
. Similar to Section 3, in the following, we propose some distance and similarity measures based on geometric distance model and set-theoretic approach:

div.head: 1) Similarity and distance measures based on geometric distance model:
div.p: We first define the following distance measure of A ~ and B ~:

The distance measure (88) involves not only the lower and upper limits of the membership degree and the non-membership degree describing IVIFSs, but also the positive parameter α . Especially, if 1 = α , then (88) is reduced to the weighted Hamming distance: 89) is reduced to the normalized Hamming distance:
, then (120) and ( 121) become ( 126) and (127), respectively:

Clearly, the similarity measure (124) is based on the weighted Hamming distance and Hausdorff metric, and the similarity measure (126) is based on the weighted Euclidean distance and Hausdorff metric, while the similarity measures (125) and (127) are the continuous counterparts of the similarity measures (124) and (126), respectively.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this paper, we have made a comprehensive overview of distance and similarity measures of IFSs. The existing distance and similarity measures of IFSs are mainly based on geometric distance model and set-theoretic approach, and the most widely used tools are the Hamming distance, Euclidean distance and Hausdorff distance. We have proposed some new distance and similarity measures of IFSs based on the continuous universe of discourse. Consider that there has been no investigation on distance and similarity measures of IVIFSs since the appearance of the IVIFS theory, we have also developed some distance and similarity measures of IVIFSs on the basis of the Hamming distance, Euclidean distance and Hausdorff distance. Clearly, all the existing and developed distance and similarity measures of IFSs or IVIFSs are just the applications of the arithmetic mean and generalized arithmetic mean aggregation operators in intuitionistic fuzzy environments.

Other kinds of aggregation operators, such as the ordered weighted averaging (OWA) operator [35], the weighted OWA operator [36,37], the uncertain OWA operator [38,39], and Sugeno integral [40], etc., might be used as a tool to develop distance and similarity measures for IFSs or IVIFSs, which is an interesting and promising topic for future research.
